question: My best ideas at work come from an interchange of ideas and sharing with others.
When I run a meeting, I am usually disciplined about following my prepared agenda.
When handling a subordinate's development, I am most likely to  discuss a problem I have with his or her behavior.
I prefer the place I work to be structured with clear rules and regulations.
I would rather have a supervisor with whom I have a lot of day-by-day interaction.
I prefer meetings where most time is spent on the application of the ideas discussed.
I prefer a work environment where frequent differences of opinion breed interesting discussions and ideas.
I prefer projects at work to be well-defined and planned out.
I prefer to spend my lunch hour eating with a group.
If my boss gives me a difficult task, I usually collect as much information as possible before starting.
In a performance appraisal, I prefer my boss to write that I am intelligent and reasonable.
I prefer to  plan my workday carefully in advance.
I more often prefer to keep my office door open.
When a new idea flashes into my mind, I usually like to test if carefully before I get excited.
In a team meeting, I prefer to emphasize an analytical discussion of the facts.
I prefer a job in which the rewards are seen clearly in regular periods.
I dress for work so that other people notice and admire my clothing.
When I solve problems, I am more likely to  give most weight to the facts in front of me.
If I have to confront colleagues or subordinates, I am usually interested in making sure I give them the facts accurately.
I would rather have a boss who provides a lot of structure and organization.
I prefer most of my jobs at work to be a continuing series of short tasks.
When I write a report, I usually think first of  the details.
When I have a decision to make at work, I usually reason it through regardless of my feelings.
I prefer my own office to be one in which things are olderly, organized, and systematic.
When I have lunch with my colleagues, I would rather talk about people.
I would rather have my boss trust me with practical problems to solve.
When faced with a decision at work, I usually prefer to  think things through.
I prefer the work I do every day to  be continuous and relatively predictable.
When I have to organize and run a meeting, I more often feel satisfied that I have the opportunity to lead.
If I were asked to prepare a strategic plan, I would be more likely to  emphasize what is practical now.
When faced with a decision at work, I usually focus on the facts and figures above all.
When my boss gives me a new project, I usually prefer a clear statement of what is expected.
I prefer to have a large group of colleagues at work.
In one-on-one meetings, I am more likely to  listen quietly and absorb details.
If someone argues with a policy or decision I make, I usually remain firm.
When I have made a tough choice at work, I usually am satisfied that it is done.
When I attend a company outing, I usually walk around and meet people I may not know well.
I think my colleagues see me more as a here-and-now person.
When I have a long and complex report to read, I am more likely to  be patient and study the details.
I prefer my work environment to be  comfortable, predictable, and stable.
My colleagues at work are more likely to describe me as  an energetic team player.
When I prepare a presentation, I prefer to emphasize the use of real facts from my own experience.
I prefer to work with colleagues who rely heavily on logic.
If someone on my team is late with a scheduled task, I usually get impatient and annoyed.
When I attend a training session, I am more likely to  participate openly and actively.
When colleagues and subordinates present ideas to me, I am usually more interested in  immediately useful ideas.
If I have to deal with a colleague's feelings, I prefer to be  truthful even if I can't be tactful.
I prefer projects that  have a clear ending date when I know they will be finished.
When I have a decision to make at work, I more often talk it over with a number of people before I decide.
I prefer a job where I can  use my experience to work at familiar tasks.
When I am at a meeting and a difference of opinion gets heated, I usually defend the side I think is most logical.
When I get a new project, I usually prefer to  get to it and complete it as quickly as possible.
I am more interested in  the actual tasks I am doing day-by-day.
When I attend a training session, I usually prefer experiential processes.
When I have a meeting with a colleague, I usually get through it quickly in a businesslike manner.
I would rather be in a job with  activities requiring me to reach a conclusion.
When I ask a colleague for advice or help, I am usually comfortable.
In a meeting or when reading a report, I am more likely to  remember the facts presented.
When colleagues ask my advice about a work matter, I more often guide them toward a decision based purely on logic.
When I am in a meeting, I am usually more interested in  getting the job done as quickly as possible.
When I am interrupted in the middle of a tough job, I usually welcome the opportunity to talk to someone.
When I read a report, I usually go first to  the body of detailed information.
When I am putting forward a new idea at work, I more often remain firm about the correctness of it.
If my boss insists that I schedule my workday, I feel satisfied I am organized.
When I am at a meeting and someone tells a joke, I usually laugh and think of one to tell.
In a performance appraisal, it would be more accurate if my boss said I was  practical.
I am usually more interested in how my colleagues think about problems.
When a new and unusual policy announcement is issued at work, I am usually annoyed or otherwise upset at the changes.
In a meeting, I usually speak out directly when I want to.
When I start a new project, I usually write a step-by-step plan early in the process.
When I hear a presentation from a colleague, I am more likely to be openly and intellectually critical.
If they couldn't be both, I would rather have colleagues who are  well-organized.
I would prefer to work in a company where everyone works together in an open, active environment.
I more often seek out work that applies my practical skills and nature.
When I have to make a decision at work, I am more likely to  analyze the situation logically without considering my values and feelings.
When I present my views in a meeting, I am usually decisive.
When I need to pass on an idea or information, I prefer to  talk directly to people about it.
My leadership style is best described as  practical.
In a performance appraisal meeting, I am usually more likely to  be frank and honest regardless of feelings.
When I am discussing an important issue at a meeting, I usually try to reach a definite conclusion quickly.
I enjoy more a workday filled with variety and interactions with others.
I prefer a work situation that is stable with little change.
My colleagues would be more likely to describe my behavior at work as  cool, calm, and objective.
At work, I prefer projects on which I work quickly to make a short deadline.
When I am in a meeting with colleagues and a high-ranking manager or executive comes in, I usually greet the person in a comfortable and friendly way.
When I think of my most important work assets, they are  more in the realm of the practical.
In a training session or course, I prefer a trainer who depends more on precision and logic.
I usually push my colleagues or subordinates for  quick decisions.
